article.title: Aedui

link.part: A map ofGaulin the 1st century BC, showing the location of the Aedui tribe.

article.paragraph: Aedui, Haedui or Hedui (lang-grcΑἰδούοι), were aGaulsGallicpeople ofGallia Lugdunensis, who inhabited the country between the Arar (Sane) and Liger (Loire), in today's France. Their territory thus included the greater part of the modern departments ofSane-et-Loire,Cte-d'OrandNivre.
article.heading: Geography
article.paragraph: The country of the Aedui is defined by reports of them in ancient writings. The upperLoireformed their western border,harvnbCaesarBGBook vii, Section 5.separating them from theBituriges. TheSaneformed their eastern border, separating them from theSequani.harvnbCaesarBGBook I, Section 12.The Sequani did not reside in the region of the confluence of theDoubsinto the Sane and of the latter into theRhne, as Caesar says that theHelvetii, following the pass between theJura Mountainsand the Rhne southwards, which belonged to the Sequani, plundered the territory of the Aedui.harvnbCaesarBGBook I, Section 11.These circumstances explain an apparent contradiction inStrabo, who in one sentence says that the Aedui lived between the Sane and the Doubs, and in the next, that the Sequani lived across the Sane (eastward).harvnbStraboGeographyBook 4, Chapter 3, Section 2.Both statements are true, the first in the south, and the second to the north.
article.heading: History
article.paragraph: File:Eduens denier 1st century BCE 1940mg.jpgthumbEduensFrench denierdenier, 1st century BCE, 1940mg.Hotel de la Monnaie.According toLivy(v. 34), they took part in the expedition ofBellovesusinto Italy in the 6th century BC.

BeforeJulius CaesarCaesar'stime, they had attached themselves to theAncient RomeRomans, and were honoured with the title of brothers and kinsmen of the Roman people.harvnbCaesarBGBook I, Section 33.When theSequani, their hereditary rivals, with the assistance of aGermanic peoplesGermanicchieftain namedAriovistus, defeated and massacred the Aedui at theBattle of Magetobriga, the Aedui sentDiviciacus (Aedui)Diviciacus, theDruidrydruid, to Rome to appeal to theRoman Senatesenatefor help. But his mission was unsuccessful.

On his arrival inGaul(58 BC), Caesar restored their independence. In spite of this, the Aedui joined the Gallic coalition against Caesar (B. G.vii. 42), but after the surrender ofVercingetorixatBattle of AlesiaAlesia, were glad to return to their allegiance.Caesar AugustusAugustusdismantledCitation neededMay 2009their native capitalBibracteonMont Beuvray, and substituted a new town with a half-Roman, half-Gaulish name, Augustodunum (modernAutun).

In 21, during the reign ofTiberius, they revolted underJulius Sacrovir, and seizedAugustodunum, but were soon put down by Gaius Silius (Gaius Cornelius TacitusTacitusAnnals (Tacitus)Ann.iii. 43-46). The Aedui were the first of the Gauls to receive from the emperorClaudiusthe distinction ofjus honorum; thus being the first Gauls permitted to become senators.Peoples, Nations and Cultures. General Editor Prof John Mackenzie. Weidenfeld and Nicolson. 2005.

The oration ofEumenius, in which he pleaded for the restoration of the schools of his native place Augustodunum, shows that the district was neglected. The chief magistrate of the Aedui in Caesar's time was calledVergobretus(according toTheodor MommsenMommsen, "judgment-worker"), who was elected annually, possessed powers of life and death, but was forbidden to go beyond the frontier. Certain clientes, or small communities, were also dependent upon the Aedui.

It is possible that the Aedui adopted many of the governmental practices of the Romans, such as electing magistrates and other officials. Or perhaps this was a natural development in their political system. It is thought that other Celtic tribes, such as the Remi and the Baiocasses, also elected their leaders.Citation neededNovember 2008
